Issues.Title: fix(router): run microtask outside of Angular when removing pending task
Issues.Body:
This commit updates the Router logic to schedule microtasks outside of Angular when removing pending tasks. This prevents redundant change detections since scheduling a microtask in the next tick would otherwise trigger another change detection.

cc @AndrewKushnir
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(router): run microtask outside of Angular when removing pending task" (#51163)

Issues.Title: Outdated note about standalone custom-elements?
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

Can standalone components (introduced in Angular 14) used for that purpose? It sounds like a combination of custom elements and standalone components could achieve this goal.

Thanks for all the effort that is put into this project  🙏

Issues.Title: withFetch() and router guard create random bug
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

I have a fully functional app using Angular 16.1.4 (standalone) and Electron 25. I am using the new experimental option for the `provideHttpClient()` - `withFetch()`, and the ng-select package (latest version 11.0.0) inside my app's navbar to search for users from the API (autocomplete).

Today, I added a router guard (functional guard) to my main page. The guard is something like:
 `return inject(AuthService).login()`, which creates an HTTP request to the backend. The guard is working as expected, and I've been using this approach for years.

However, the combination of `withFetch()` and the `authGuard` is causing a strange bug: The ng-select component is not working properly - it doesn't show a list of items (even though the API calls appear in the network tab), the CSS is a bit off (the input is on top of the placeholder), among other strange behaviors.

Just by removing either `withFetch()` or the authGuard, everything works as expected. So, it seems the combination of the two is creating side effects on the ng-select component.

I updated to Angular 16.1.6, but the bug persists. I have another app that works with ng-select, Angular 16, and authGuard without any issues. I have a lot of experience with Angular, and this is a strange one. I'm not sure if anyone will know the cause, especially without a reproduction of the bug. But if no one has a clue, I'll do my best to reproduce it.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
No errors on the console at all.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular: 16.1.4 \ 6
Node: 16.19.1

Electron: 25
```


### Anything else?

I am running angular inside electron app, but this is not releated to Electron in my opinion, since I can also run the angular app in the browser directly (localhost:4200) and I see the same behaviour.

- Everything is working as expected without the guard
- If the guard is not using http request (ie, just returns of(true)) - no problem
- No errors in the console, the http requests for the guard and the ng-select autocomplete is working and getting valid respones (200) using fetch api
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "withFetch() and router guard create random bug" (#51181)

Issues.Title: [WIP] refactor(compiler): apply component metadata asynchronously when defer blocks are present
Issues.Body:
⚠️ **Disclaimer** ⚠️ **this PR uses a syntax that is still in an open RFC. It will be adjusted once the RFC is closed.**

**NOTE**: this PR is based on top of PR #51162, so only the last commit (https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/83b02bb5accc7297e7a45732d2363aa5f4072a92) contains a new change.

This commit updates compiler logic to generate the `setClassMetadataAsync` calls for components that used defer blocks. The `setClassMetadataAsync` function loads deferrable dependencies and invokes the `setClassMetadata` synchronously once everything is loaded. This change is needed to avoid eager references to deferrable symbols in component metadata in generated code.

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)

Issues.Title: Effects don't work after updating from @angular/cli 14.2.11 to 14.2.12
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Hi at all,

after upgrading to angular/cli 14.2.12 all my NgRx effects using fetch() are broken: 

Example code: 

```
downloadInvoice$ = createEffect(() =>
        this.actions$.pipe(
            ofType(TasksActions.downloadInvoice),
            fetch({
                run: (action: ReturnType<typeof TasksActions.downloadInvoice>) =>
                    TaskUtil.loadInvoicePdf(action.orderId, this.taskService).pipe(
                        map(() => TasksActions.downloadInvoiceSuccess())
                    ),
                onError: (action: ReturnType<typeof TasksActions.downloadInvoice>, error: any) =>
                    TasksActions.downloadInvoiceError({ error })

            })
        )
    );
```

When reverting to 14.2.11 everything runs like clockwork again.

Issues.Title: refactor(core): throw an error when hydration marker is missing from DOM
Issues.Body:
Non-destructive hydration expects the DOM tree to have the same structure in both places. With this commit, the app will throw an error if comments are stripped out by the http server (eg by some CDNs).

fixes #51160

I'll create a dedicate doc for the error in a subsequent PR.

Issues.Title: Signal subscription counter
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

My scenario is that we have a store and when you use the object in a lot of places at some point you want to check if its still needed and if not garbage collect that object by remove it from the list and freeing up memory.

We use ofc Behavior/ReplaySubject-s for it however I wonder if it would be possible to do it with signals since they are going to be long term a better and more performant solution.

### Proposed solution

signalObject.subscriptionCount //gives you the number of subscriptions that the signal holds
signalObject.subscriptionChangeEvent //some event that will let you know if the subscription number has changed so you can update your view, create new Date etc

### Alternatives considered

Please consider that this is really really mandatory for some enterprise solution cause in other way I would have to still keep using the Subjects patterns to monitor how many things are subscribed/unsubscribed and when the subscriptionCount fell to 0.

Or offer me some alternative solution but I kind of don't like the option to transform it to a observable and then in each component transform it back to an signal. Sounds pretty memory intensive pattern.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Signal subscription counter" (#51167)

Issues.Title: Attribute with default value doesn't accept undefined as value
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

In an Angular 16 project with strictTemplates option on, I get numerous errors in templates about the attributes.

My point in this issue is that when I have `<some-component [size]="size"/>` with the `size` attribute defined as: `@Input() size: string = DEFAULT_SIZE;` for example, I get the following error: "_TS2322: Type 'string | undefined' is not assignable to type 'string'_".

But Angular converts undefined values to the default value in such case, that's the point of the whole mechanism.
I workaround the problem with `<some-component [size]="size!"/>` but it doesn't feel right.
It worked before (v. 14), because the template compiler was less strict?

Can Angular template compiler detect such cases and avoid this error?
Thanks.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
error TS2322: Type 'string | undefined' is not assignable to type 'string'.
```

So, in the next major release, we will reintroduce method implementations that do not involve strings in the `ignore` option.

Issues.Title: Hydration: detect when index.html is altered between the server and the client
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

The non-destructive hydration expects the DOM tree to have the same structure in both places. This also includes whitespaces and comment nodes that Angular produces during the rendering on the server. Those whitespaces and nodes must be present in the HTML generated by the server-side rendering process. This is also documented at: https://angular.io/guide/hydration#constraints.

In practice, some CDNs ([example](https://developers.cloudflare.com/speed/optimization/content/auto-minify/)) have mechanisms to remove all comment nodes and spaces from all text nodes from HTML while serving the content (there are also cases where this type of optimization is performed at the build step). Those mechanisms are frequently enabled by default. This leads to situations where an application worked in dev mode correctly, but started failing in production. Since the production code is also minified, it makes it hard to look at the stack trace and identify the origin of the problem.

This feature requests proposes that we add a special detection mechanism for such cases. For example, we can do the following:

- on the server, while serializing DOM, add a comment node to a well known location (e.g. as a first node in the `<body>`)
- on the client (both in dev and prod modes), before starting hydration process, verify the presence of those "marker" nodes and throw an error if they are not present
- we should also add an error guide for this error, so that the link to the guide is present in production mode

One of the examples where this issue becomes a hard-to-debug problem: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/50133#issuecomment-1535713053
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Hydration: detect when index.html is altered between the server and the client" (#51160)

Issues.Title: feat(core): Provide a diagnostic for negated `AsyncPipe` in ngIf expressions
Issues.Body:
Negating an `AsyncPipe` in an `*ngIf` thrashes the layout because the pipe emits null immediately before checking the condition. This can lead cause unnecessary rendering.

This commit adds an extended diagnostic to produce a warning when an `AsyncPipe` is negated in an `ngIf` expression. 

I know we're expecting to deprecate `ngif` with the new control flow syntax but it could still be a interesting diagnostic for existing templates. (Or is it ?) 

fixes #44867
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(core): Provide a diagnostic for negated `AsyncPipe` in ngIf expressions" (#51158)

Issues.Title: Dynamic components aren't hydrated when root component is used as an anchor
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

platform-browser

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

As in the linked reproduction, I'm dynamically creating a component like so:

```
import('./foo/foo.component').then((m) => {
  this.vcr.createComponent(m.FooComponent);
});
```

The component correctly appears in the SSR output. However, Angular does not appear to hydrate the component. Instead, it creates a _new_ instance, and leaves the existing copy in the DOM dehydrated (and thus, broken), even after hydration completes.

https://codesandbox.io/p/sandbox/unruffled-dawn-dngll7

Issues.Title: Remove regex file type check on fileReplacements
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

Currently when we use `fileReplacements` it will check the files for this regex pattern: `\.(([cm]?j|t)sx?|json)$`. I found it out by trying to replace `robots.production.txt` into `robots.txt`.

This is the config that I am using that throws this error:

```json
{
  "replace": "src/robots.txt",
  "with": "src/robots.production.txt"
}
```

The question is: Why limit file types onto this setting? I don't see the benefit and only drawbacks as I have experienced currently.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would like to remove regex filetype check on `fileReplacements` property.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Only alternative is to run a custom shell script that would do it for me before running `npm run build:production`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Remove regex file type check on fileReplacements" (#25599)

Issues.Title: hmr can be broken when using module federation with shared config
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

https://webpack.js.org/concepts/module-federation/#uncaught-error-shared-module-is-not-available-for-eager-consumption

When `@angular/core` is shared with `eager: false`, this will result

```
Uncaught Error: Shared module is not available for eager consumption
```

at https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/d4e541db3e4b495888f8b653d2141be112e7eef5/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/tools/webpack/plugins/hmr/hmr-loader.ts#L22-L23

This can be fixed easily with:

```diff
-  import ngHmrAccept from '${hmrAcceptPath}';
-  ngHmrAccept(module);
+  import('${hmrAcceptPath}').then(({default:ngHmrAccept})=>ngHmrAccept(module));
```

### Minimal Reproduction

N/A

### Exception or Error

_No response_

### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 16.1.3
Node: 18.17.0
Package Manager: yarn 1.22.19
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: 16.1.3
... animations, cdk, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core
... forms, language-service, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router

---------------------------------------------------------

@angular-devkit/core            16.1.3
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.1.3
@schematics/angular             16.1.3

```

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint (@​typescript-eslint/parser)</summary>

### [`v6.2.0`](https://togithub.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/blob/HEAD/packages/parser/CHANGELOG.md#620-2023-07-24)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/compare/v6.1.0...v6.2.0)

**Note:** Version bump only for package [@​typescript-eslint/parser](https://togithub.com/typescript-eslint/parser)

You can read about our [versioning strategy](https://main--typescript-eslint.netlify.app/users/versioning) and [releases](https://main--typescript-eslint.netlify.app/users/releases) on our website.

</details>

<details>
<summary>evanw/esbuild (esbuild)</summary>

### [`v0.18.17`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#01817)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.18.16...v0.18.17)

-   Support `An+B` syntax and `:nth-*()` pseudo-classes in CSS

    This adds support for the `:nth-child()`, `:nth-last-child()`, `:nth-of-type()`, and `:nth-last-of-type()` pseudo-classes to esbuild, which has the following consequences:

    -   The [`An+B` syntax](https://drafts.csswg.org/css-syntax-3/#anb-microsyntax) is now parsed, so parse errors are now reported
    -   `An+B` values inside these pseudo-classes are now pretty-printed (e.g. a leading `+` will be stripped because it's not in the AST)
    -   When minification is enabled, `An+B` values are reduced to equivalent but shorter forms (e.g. `2n+0` => `2n`, `2n+1` => `odd`)
    -   Local CSS names in an `of` clause are now detected (e.g. in `:nth-child(2n of :local(.foo))` the name `foo` is now renamed)

    ```css
    /* Original code */
    .foo:nth-child(+2n+1 of :local(.bar)) {
      color: red;
    }

    /* Old output (with --loader=local-css) */
    .stdin_foo:nth-child(+2n + 1 of :local(.bar)) {
      color: red;
    }

    /* New output (with --loader=local-css) */
    .stdin_foo:nth-child(2n+1 of .stdin_bar) {
      color: red;
    }
    ```

-   Adjust CSS nesting parser for IE7 hacks ([#​3272](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3272))

    This fixes a regression with esbuild's treatment of IE7 hacks in CSS. CSS nesting allows selectors to be used where declarations are expected. There's an IE7 hack where prefixing a declaration with a `*` causes that declaration to only be applied in IE7 due to a bug in IE7's CSS parser. However, it's valid for nested CSS selectors to start with `*`. So esbuild was incorrectly parsing these declarations and anything following it up until the next `{` as a selector for a nested CSS rule. This release changes esbuild's parser to terminate the parsing of selectors for nested CSS rules when a `;` is encountered to fix this edge case:

    ```css
    /* Original code */
    .item {
      *width: 100%;
      height: 1px;
    }

    /* Old output */
    .item {
      *width: 100%; height: 1px; {
      }
    }

    /* New output */
    .item {
      *width: 100%;
      height: 1px;
    }
    ```

    Note that the syntax for CSS nesting is [about to change again](https://togithub.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7961), so esbuild's CSS parser may still not be completely accurate with how browsers do and/or will interpret CSS nesting syntax. Expect additional updates to esbuild's CSS parser in the future to deal with upcoming CSS specification changes.

-   Adjust esbuild's warning about undefined imports for TypeScript `import` equals declarations ([#​3271](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3271))

    In JavaScript, accessing a missing property on an import namespace object is supposed to result in a value of `undefined` at run-time instead of an error at compile-time. This is something that esbuild warns you about by default because doing this can indicate a bug with your code. For example:

    ```js
    // app.js
    import * as styles from './styles'
    console.log(styles.buton)
    ```

    ```js
    // styles.js
    export let button = {}
    ```

    If you bundle `app.js` with esbuild you will get this:

        ▲ [WARNING] Import "buton" will always be undefined because there is no matching export in "styles.js" [import-is-undefined]

            app.js:2:19:
              2 │ console.log(styles.buton)
                │                    ~~~~~
                ╵                    button

          Did you mean to import "button" instead?

            styles.js:1:11:
              1 │ export let button = {}
                ╵            ~~~~~~

    However, there is TypeScript-only syntax for `import` equals declarations that can represent either a type import (which esbuild should ignore) or a value import (which esbuild should respect). Since esbuild doesn't have a type system, it tries to only respect `import` equals declarations that are actually used as values. Previously esbuild always generated this warning for unused imports referenced within `import` equals declarations even when the reference could be a type instead of a value. Starting with this release, esbuild will now only warn in this case if the import is actually used. Here is an example of some code that no longer causes an incorrect warning:

    ```ts
    // app.ts
    import * as styles from './styles'
    import ButtonType = styles.Button
    ```

    ```ts
    // styles.ts
    export interface Button {}
    ```

</details>

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): error during critical CSS inlining for external stylesheets
Issues.Body:
These changes revert the performance improvement from https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/24925/commits/e88aea65bdb66fa4e9c6ad580ff733642e1fb24c and add a test. The problem with the previous approach is that it assumes that a `link` tag processed by Critters will be preceded by a `style` tag that was inserted by Critters. This assumption might not necessarily be true if Critters is unable to resolve the content of the linked styles. Furthermore, I'm not sure if we need to optimize this code path to begin with, because it only does a shallow traversal of the `head` tag which is generally fast and is unlikely to have many direct descendants.

Fixes #25419.

Issues.Title: Bug: "link.prev?.setAttribute is not a function" - CSP and <link rel="stylesheet">
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

ng build breaks when we combine ngCspNonce with a hard-coded style-sheet link in index.html.

We can replicate this in a new angular app. However, this problem first appeared for us in an Angular Universal app, with the following setup:
- We add ngCspNonce to the app-root as explained in: https://angular.io/guide/security#content-security-policy
- We also add some external style-sheets as links in index.html.

We believe this is where the bug occurs
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/utils/index-file/inline-critical-css.ts#L149

### Minimal Reproduction

How to reproduce:
1. Run ng new
2. Add ngCspNonce to index.html (nonce is hardcoded for testability)
3. Add a stylesheet link to head: `<link rel="stylesheet" href="..." />`
4. Run ng build, and see error

Repo with minimal reproduction: https://github.com/majoer/angular-csp-link-bug

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): correctly load dev server assets with vite 4.4.0+
Issues.Body:
The underlying development server (Vite) for the application build system updated
its static file serving dependencies which resulted in the `@fs` special file URLs
supported by Vite to have a different format.  Previously, the paths were encoded
using `encodeURIComponent` but are now use `encodeURI`. The development server
integration with Vite will now use the matching encoding to allow build defined
assets to be correctly served.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): correctly load dev server assets with vite 4.4.0+" (#25577)

Issues.Title: Add more description to ng generate subcommands
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

Some newcomers like me didn't know what happens when I run `ng g component whatever` and `ng g service whatever`:

The description is too vague and you get confused at first what these commands do to the file system and how they name the API item and the component selector, so can you add a little more detail to `--help`?

### Proposed solution

Add more detail:

- `ng g component --help` (`<name>`)
  - Generates a directory at `name`. The last portion of `name` is the selector (or API item name), adding a `app-` prefix by default.
- `ng g service --help` (`<name>`)
  - Generates a service and its spec at `name` (not at a new directory).

### Alternatives considered

N/A

Issues.Title: feat(youtube-player): Support looping of video
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

Provide a property that allows looping to be enabled so that the video is automatically restarted upon completion.  Currently, this has to be accomplished by monitoring for `stateChange`, then manually calling `playVideo()` once `getPlayerState()` reports 0 (zero).  

Incidentally, this has to be done using the native object (passed via `$event`) - it does not work if trying to call `playVideo()` from a reference to the `YouTubePlayer` object obtained via `ViewChild()` for some reason.  The object is present and properties seem to be available.  But calling `playVideo()` on that object doesn't work.  I have to call it on `$event.target`.

Issues.Title: bug(youtube-player): videoId required for initialization
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Using `playerVars`, it is possible to specify a video/list to play upon initialization - eliminating the (redundant) need to specify a `videoId` property.  However, the player won't initialize if `videoId` is missing.

### Reproduction

`<youtube-player [playerVars]="playerVars"></youtube-player>`

```
playerVars = {
    list: 'LISTID',
    listtype: 'playlist'
  };
```

### Expected Behavior

If video is specified in `playerVars`, don't require `videoId` property to have a value

### Actual Behavior

No player displayed when `videoId` is missing

### Environment

- Angular: 16.1.6
- Operating System: Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(youtube-player): videoId required for initialization" (#27529)

Issues.Title: bug(youtube-player): PlayerVars
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

`PlayerVars` object support was implemented, however `listType` seems to not be working, or I'm not able to figure it out.  The documentation for this component is still poor, so it's entirely possible that I'm not understanding the proper use.

According to the [YouTube documentation](https://developers.google.com/youtube/player_parameters), `listType` can be `playlist` or `user_uploads`.  However, the Angular project will not build successfully when I attempt to set `listType` to any value.  There also doesn't seem to be a `ListType` enum exposed, like some of the other properties (such as `AutoPlay`, etc.).  This would be helpful in feeding it a proper value since it clearly doesn't like the strings `playlist` or `user_uploads`.

Looking in the "Type definitions for YouTube", it seems like there _should_ be `ListType` type exported, but I'm not sure how to make use of it and I'm not seeing it in the `YT` namespace.  Interestingly, the index.d.ts file for the type definitions defines the first potential value for `ListType` as `player` - not `playlist`.  This seems to be inconsistent with the YouTube documentation.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
`<youtube-player [playerVars]="playerVars"></youtube-player>`

```
playerVars = {
    autoplay: 1,
    controls: 1,
    list: 'LISTID',
    listType: 'playlist',
    modestbranding: 1
  };
```

### Expected Behavior

Full support for the PlayerVars object, per the YouTube documentation

### Actual Behavior

build errors:

```
Types of property 'listType' are incompatible.
    Type 'string' is not assignable to type 'ListType | undefined'
```

### Environment

- Angular: 16.1.6
- Operating System: Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(youtube-player): PlayerVars" (#27528)

Issues.Title: feat(sort): add manual sort
Issues.Body:
make the `sort` method of `MatSort` accept new interface `MatManualSort` which has the exact direction the developer wants to be it's fully compatible with the current code
use case that's currently not possible: changing currently set desc to asc using the new interface will make the sort method idempotent

Closes #27515
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(sort): add manual sort" (#27516)

Issues.Title: feat(sort): add ability to change sort direction
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

right now you can only change the sort start, not the actual direction, which require us to do dirty hacks to do it, for example to change from asc to desc we call sort twice, which generate two https calls, we need to add debouncetime in the http call to prevent this, but there are other scenarios

### Use Case

it will simplify changing sort programmatically, since now it's only doable to go from asc to desc to unsorted
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(sort): add ability to change sort direction" (#27515)

Issues.Title: bug(CdkMenu): Opening submenu requires two clicks on touch display (Chrome)
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When opening a submenu created using CdkMenu via touch interaction on a touch display, the first click on the CdkMenuItem does not open the corresponding submenu. Only the second click opens the submenu.

This can be reproduced on Chrome (v115 - latest as of 2023-07-25) on both macOs and Windows 10.

### Reproduction

Example on the Angular CDK website: https://material.angular.io/cdk/menu/examples#cdk-menu-menubar

1. using a touch display or touch emulation on Chrome, click on the parent menu item "File".
2. click on the submenu item "New"
3. you will see that the menu item is briefly animated, but the menu does not open
4. click the "New" menu item again and the submenu will open.

Issue can be reproduced on the Angular CDK website or the StackBlitz link provided in the example

Video showing the bug:
https://github.com/angular/components/assets/6468359/0b9dff7a-68e1-49cc-96fd-0d887e4e704c

### Expected Behavior

Only one click should be necessary to open the submenu using touch interaction on a touch display.

### Actual Behavior

Two clicks are necessary to open the submenu.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.1.1
- CDK/Material: 16.1.5
- Browser(s): Chrome Version 115.0.5790.102 (Official Build) (x86_64) (latest as of 2023-07-25)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):	Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (Version 10.0.19045 Build 19045), macOS Monterey (Version 12.6.3 (21G419))
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(CdkMenu): Opening submenu requires two clicks on touch display (Chrome)" (#27508)

When adding the 'disableRipple' property to a material button, this should stop adding a ripple effect for when the button is clicked. Instead the ripple is still enabled.

Issues.Title: bug(themes): Using themes with global css vars is not working
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

I am trying to customize the snackbar notifications and use a Material Theme.
The following css works: 

```
.success-notification-overlay {
        --mdc-snackbar-container-color: green;
        --mat-mdc-snack-bar-button-color: yellow;
        --mdc-snackbar-supporting-text-color: red;
    }
```

The following css does not work: 
```
.success-notification-overlay {
        --mdc-snackbar-container-color: mat.get-color-from-palette($accent-palette);
        --mat-mdc-snack-bar-button-color: mat.get-color-from-palette($accent-palette, default-contrast);
        --mdc-snackbar-supporting-text-color: mat.get-color-from-palette($accent-palette, default-contrast);
    }
```

Using color/background I can use mat.get-color-from-palette, but it seems like [this is not supported/wanted any longer](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/26928). 

Did anyone get this to work?


### Reproduction

Couldn't set up a fully replicating example quickly, but something like this: 

https://stackblitz.com/edit/9dxzn2-tnc3oh?file=src%2Ftheme.scss,src%2Fexample%2Fsnack-bar-position-example.theme.scss,src%2Fexample%2Fsnack-bar-position-example.scss,src%2Fexample%2Fsnack-bar-position-example.ts,.gitignore

### Expected Behavior

The colors from the theme palette should be resolved and used

### Actual Behavior

The function for getting the color is output into the generated css: 
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/18051404/63d9b782-432c-4bb6-b990-f3f442092d57)


### Environment

- Angular: 16.0.0
- CDK/Material: 16.0.0
- Browser(s): Chrome Version 114.0.5735.248
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(themes): Using themes with global css vars is not working" (#27504)
